title: Authors and Citation
text: Sar Lindner. Author, maintainer, copyright holder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Lindner S (2025). ecotools: Tools Field Ecologist. R package version 1.0.2, https://github.com/sarlindner/ecotools.
code: @Manual{,   title = {ecotools: Tools for the Field Ecologist},   author = {Sar Lindner},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 1.0.2},   url = {https://github.com/sarlindner/ecotools}, }

title: Tools for the Field Ecologist

what: Calculates overstory density from densiometer readings — densiometer
title: Calculates overstory density from densiometer readings — densiometer
text: densiometer() takes data frame containing readings spherical crown densiometer, averages , uses densiometer conversion factor calculate overstory/canopy density given field location site observation.

title: Calculates overstory density from densiometer readings — densiometer
Calculates overstory density from densiometer readings — densiometer
text: data Data frame field data. ... Columns data frame containing densiometer     readings. Can add number readings averaged.

title: Calculates overstory density from densiometer readings — densiometer
text: data frame additional column, "over_dens",   containing computed overstory density values.

title: Calculates overstory density from densiometer readings — densiometer
code: # Example data frame with one row of data df <- data.frame(dens_A = 95, dens_B = 96, dens_C = 93, dens_D = 91)  # Function with inputs df <- densiometer(df, dens_A:dens_D)  # Data frame will now contain one column, "over_dens", with computed value. print(df) #>   over_dens #> 1       2.5

what: Models binary field data over time — model_time
title: Models binary field data over time — model_time
text: model_time() takes presence/absence data field, camera trap data, models relationship binary presence/absence data kind environmental variable time. function produce simple line graph plot provides overview relationship.

title: Models binary field data over time — model_time
code: model_time(data, date, variable, binary_col, x_lab = "date", y_lab = variable, title = "", legend = "")

title: Models binary field data over time — model_time
text: data Binary field data. date Date/timescale. Entered "column_name". variable Environmental variable. Entered "column_name". binary_col Binary data - ones zeroes. Entered "column_name". x_lab x-axis label. Default `date`. y_lab x-axis label. Default name `variable`. title Title. Default empty. legend Legend label. Default empty.

title: Models binary field data over time — model_time
text: plot modeling relationship time   environmental variable binary data coded color.

title: Models binary field data over time — model_time
code: # Example camera trap data df <- data.frame(     date =c("4/17", "4/18", "4/19", "4/20", "4/21"),     temp = c(40, 60, 42, 45, 52),     binary_col = c(0, 1, 0, 0, 1) )  # Creates plot plot <- model_time(df, "date", "temp", "binary_col")

what: Models binary field data with an environmental variable — model_var
title: Models binary field data with an environmental variable — model_var
text: model_var() takes presence/absence data models relationship binary data environmental variable individual observation - species, location, occurance. function produce simple scatter point plot generalized linear regression model observations specified get quick overview rough significance.

title: Models binary field data with an environmental variable — model_var
code: model_var(data, variable, binary_col, var_label = variable, binary_label = "presence/absence", title = "")

title: Models binary field data with an environmental variable — model_var
text: data Binary field data. variable Environmental variable. Entered "column_name". binary_col Binary data - ones zeroes. Entered "column_name". var_label Label variable. Default name `variable`. binary_label Label binary column. Default "presence/absence". title Title. Default empty.

title: Models binary field data with an environmental variable — model_var
text: plot modeling relationship envrionmental variable   ecological presence absence.

title: Models binary field data with an environmental variable — model_var
code: # Example binary field data df <- data.frame(   temp = c(40, 42, 44, 46, 48, 50, 52, 54, 56, 58),   binary_col = c(0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1) )  # Creates plot plot <- model_var(df, "temp", "binary_col", var_label = "Temperature F")

title: Summary of presence/absence observations — obs_sum
text: obs_sum() takes data frame field data prints summary frequency "present" vs. "absent" observations.

title: Summary of presence/absence observations — obs_sum
Summary of presence/absence observations — obs_sum
text: data Binary field data. binary_col Binary data - ones zeroes. Entered "column_name".

title: Summary of presence/absence observations — obs_sum
text: string printed console giving fraction percentage   "present" "absent" observations.

title: Summary of presence/absence observations — obs_sum
code: # Example data frame containing a column of binary data df <- data.frame(binary_col = c(1, 0, 1, 1, 0, 0, 1, 0))  # Calculating a printing the percentage of each type of observation obs_sum(df, binary_col) #> present: 4/8; 50% #> absent: 4/8; 50%

title: Prints in species case! — species_case
text: species_case() takes string two words prints "species case", genus-species scientific name format: john smith == J. smith

title: Prints in species case! — species_case
Prints in species case! — species_case
text: name character string containing two words, e.g., genus species name,   converted proper "species case".

title: Prints in species case! — species_case
text: character string input name formatted species case.

title: Prints in species case! — species_case
code: # Will print the species name in the proper format species_case("elymus virginicus") #> E. virginicus species_case("Elymus VIRGINICUS") #> E. virginicus  # Will print your name in species case! species_case("john smith") #> J. smith
